questionContent.questionText:
1. Open center of the iris through which light rays enter. [pupil]

2. Delicate membrane lining the eyelids and covering the anterior sclera of the eyeball. [conjunctiva]

3. Fibrous layer of clear tissue that extends over the anterior portion of the eyeball. [cornea] 

4. Tough, white outer layer of the eyeball. [sclera] 

5. Vascular layer of the eyeball that is continuous with the iris. [choroid] 

6. Colored portion of the eye; surrounds the pupil. [iris] 

7. Contains muscles that control the shape of the lens and secretes aqueous humor. [ciliary body] 

8. Transparent structure behind the iris and in front of the vitreous humor; it refracts light rays onto the retina. [lens] 

9. Colored portion of the eye; surrounds the pupil. [retina] 

10. Jelly-like material behind the lens that helps maintain the shape of the eyeball. [vitreous humor]

instructions.instructions: Match the structure of the eye in the dropdown with its description.

questionContent.questionText:
1 . The region at the back of the eye where the optic nerve meets the retina is the [optic disc].

2 . The normal adjustment of the lens (becoming fatter) to bring an object into focus for near vision on the retina is [accommodation].

3. A small, oval region on the retina lateral to the optic disc is the [macula]. 

4. The tiny pit or depression in the retina that is the region of clearest vision is the [fovea centralis].

5. The bending of light rays by the cornea, lens, and ﬂuids of the eye is [refraction].

6. The point at which the ﬁbers of the optic nerve cross in the brain is the [optic chiasm].

7. The photoreceptor cells in the retina that make the perception of color possible are the [cones].

8. The photoreceptor cells in the retina that make vision in dim light possible are the [rods].

9. The [anterior chamber] is the area behind the cornea and in front of the lens and iris. It contains aqueous humor.

10. The posterior, inner part of the eye is the [fundus].

instructions.instructions: Supply the terms that complete the following sentences.

readingPart.reading:
anterior chamber and aqueous humoroptic nerve fibers
cerebral cortex (occipital lobe)pupil
cornearetina
lensthalamus
optic chiasmvitreous chamber and vitreous humor

questionContent.questionText:
1. [cornea] ﬁbrous transparent layer of clear tissue over the eyeball

2. [anterior chamber and aqueous humor] space and ﬂuid in the front of the eye

3. [pupil] central opening of the iris

4. [lens] transparent, biconvex body that refracts light rays

5. [vitreous chamber and vitreous humor] space and soft, jelly-like material in the posterior (back) of eye

6. [retina] light-sensitive inner nerve cell layer; rods and cones

7. [optic nerve ﬁbers] cranial nerve

8. [optic chiasm] area of brain where optic nerve ﬁbers cross

9. [thalamus] relay center of the brain 

10. [cerebral cortex (occipital lobe)] visual region of the brain

instructions.instructions: Arrange the following terms in proper sequence to show the pathway of light rays to the visual region of the brain.

readingPart.reading: cranial nerve that carries implses from the retina to the brain
having two sides that are rounded, elevated, and curved evenly
condition of pupils of unequal (anis/o) size
pertaining to paralysis of the ciliary muscles, which would result in dilation or enlargement of the pupil
pertaining to the eyelid
condition of enlargement of the pupil
condition of constriction of the pupil
swelling in the region of the optic disc
condition of sensitivity to (“fear of”) light
blind spot; area of darkened (diminished) vision surrounded by clear vision

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. inﬂammation of an eyelid: [blephar]itis

2. inﬂammation of the conjunctiva: [conjunctiv]itis

3. inﬂammation of a tear gland: [dacryoaden]itis

4. inﬂammation of the iris: [ir]itis

5. inﬂammation of the cornea: [kerat]itis

6. inﬂammation of the white of the eye: [scler]itis

7. inﬂammation of the retina: [retin]itis

8. prolapse of the eyelid: blephar[optosis]

9. pertaining to tears: [lacrim]al 

10. pertaining to within the eye: intra[ocular]

instructions.instructions: Complete the medical terms based on their meanings and the word parts given.

readingPart.reading:
aphakiahemianopsiaoptometrist
corneal ulcerophthalmologistuveitis
esotropiaopticianxerophthalmia
exotropia

questionContent.questionText:
1. Fibrous layer of clear tissue over the front of the eyeball has a defect resulting from infection: [corneal ulcer]

2. Inﬂammation of the vascular layer of the eye (iris, ciliary body, and choroid): [uveitis]

3. Condition of dry eyes: [xerophthalmia]

4. Absence of vision in half of the visual ﬁeld: [hemianopsia]

5. Eye abnormally turns outward: [exotropia]    

6. Medical doctor who treats diseases of the eyes: [ophthalmologist]

7. Nonmedical professional who can examine eyes and prescribe glasses: [optometrist]

8. Nonmedical professional who grinds lenses and ﬁts glasses: [optician]

9. Absence of the lens of the eye: [aphakia]

10. Eye abnormally turns inward: [esotropia]

instructions.instructions: Select from the list of terms to match the descriptions/deﬁnitions that follow

readingPart.reading: decreased (dim) vision; lazy eye (resulting from strabismus and uncorrected refractive errors in childhood)
farsightedness
decreased vision at near, resulting from increasing age
nearsightedness
night blindness; decreased vision at night
double vision
defective curvature of the lens and/or cornea leading to blurred vision

instructions.instructions: Describe the following visual conditions.

questionContent.questionText:
1. In the myopic eye, light rays do not focus properly on the [retina]. Either the eyeball is too [long] or the refractive power of the lens is too [strong], so that the image is blurred and comes to a focus in [front] of the retina. The type of lens used to correct this refractive error is called a/an [concave] lens.

2. In the hyperopic eye, the eyeball is too [short] or the refractive power of the lens too [weak], so that the image is blurred and focused in [back/behind] of the retina. The type of lens used to correct this refractive error is called a/an [convex] lens.

3. Amiotic is a drug that [constricts] the pupil of the eye.

4. Amydriatic is a drug that [dilates ] the pupil of the eye.

instructions.instructions: Complete the following sentences.

readingPart.reading:
cataracthordeolum (stye)retinal detachment
chalazionmacular degenerationretinitis pigmentosa
diabetic retinopathynystagmusstrabismus
glaucoma

questionContent.questionText:
1. Retinal microaneurysms, hemorrhages, dilation of retinal veins, and neovascularization occur secondary to an abnormal endocrine condition: [diabetic retinopathy]

2. Two layers of the retina separate from each other: [retinal detachment]

3. Abnormal deviations of the eye occur (esotropia and exotropia): [strabismus]

4. Clouding of the lens causes decreased vision: [cataract]

5. Loss of central vision caused by deterioration of the macula of the retina: [macular degeneration]

6. Localized, purulent infection of a sebaceous gland in the eyelid: [hordeolum (stye)]

7. Small, ﬁrm, cystic mass on the eyelid; formed as a result of chronic inﬂammation of a sebaceous gland: [chalazion]

8. Increased intraocular pressure results in optic nerve damage: [glaucoma]

9. Pigmented scarring forms throughout the retina: [retinitis pigmentosa]

10. Repetitive rhythmic movements of one or both eyes: [nystagmus]

1. [pupil]
2. [conjunctiva]

9. [anterior chamber]

13. [optic disc]
14. [macula]
15. [fovea centralis]

1. lacrim/o [tears]

2. dacry/o [tears]

3. kerat/o [cornea]

4. corne/o [cornea]

5. blephar/o [eyelid]

6. palpebr/o [eyelid]

instructions.instructions: Give the meaning of the following combining forms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. OU [both eyes/each eye]

2. VA [visual acuity]

3. OD [right eye]

4. OS [left eye]

5. VF [visual field]

6. IOL [intraocular lens]

7. IOP [intraocular pressure]

8. PERRLA [pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation]

9. OCT [optical coherence tomography ]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following abbreviations for terms relating to the eye or ear.

readingPart.reading:
fluorescein angiographyophthalmoscopytonometry
keratoplastyphacoemulsificationvisual acuity test
laser photocoagulationscleral bucklevisual field test
LASIKslit lamp microscopyvitrectomy

questionContent.questionText:
1. Ultrasonic vibrations break up the lens, and the fragments are aspirated from the eye: [phacoemulsiﬁcation]

2. Test of clearness of vision: [visual acuity test]

3. Measurement of tension or pressure within the eye; glaucoma test: [tonometry]

4. High-energy light radiation beams are used to stop retinal hemorrhaging: [laser photocoagulation]

5. A laser removes corneal tissue (sculpts it) to correct myopia: [LASIK]

6. Intravenous injection of dye followed by photographs of the eye through dilated pupils: [ﬂuorescein angiography]

7. Suture of a silicone band to the sclera to correct retinal detachment: [scleral buckle]

8. Test to measure central and peripheral vision (area within which objects are seen) when the eyes are looking straight ahead: [visual ﬁeld test]

9. Removal (and replacement) of diseased ﬂuid in the chamber behind the lens of the eye: [vitrectomy]

10. Visual examination of the interior of the eye after dilation of the pupil: [ophthalmoscopy]    

11. Use of an instrument for microscopic examination of parts of the eye: [slit lamp microscopy]

12. Corneal transplant surgery: [keratoplasty ]

instructions.instructions: Arrange the following terms in the correct order to indicate their sequence in the transmission of sound waves to the brain from the outer ear.

readingPart.reading: cochlea and organs of equilibrium (semicircular canals and vestibule)
organ of equilibrium in the inner ear
passageway between the middle ear and the throat
third ossicle (little bone) of the middle ear
region in the cochlea that contains auditory receptors
auditory ﬂuids circulating within the inner ear
wax in the external auditory meatus
central cavity of the inner ear that connects the semicircular canals and the cochlea
delicate membrane between the middle and the inner ears
eardrum

instructions.instructions: Give short deﬁnitions for the following medical terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. instrument to examine the ear: [oto]scope

2. removal of the third bone of the middle ear: [staped]ectomy

3. pertaining to the auditory tube and throat: [salpingo]pharyngeal

4. ﬂow of pus from the ear: oto[pyorrhea]

5. instrument to measure hearing: [audio]meter

6. incision of the eardrum: [myringo/tympano]tomy

7. surgical repair of the eardrum: [tympano/myringo]plasty

8. deafness due to old age: [presby]cusis

9. small ear: micr[otia]

10. inﬂammation of the middle ear: ot[itis media]

instructions.instructions: Complete the following terms based on their deﬁnitions.

readingPart.reading: sensation of irregular or whirling motion either of oneself or of external objects
disorder of the labyrinth marked by elevation of ear ﬂuids and pressure within the cochlea (tinnitus, vertigo, and nausea result)
hardening in the bony tissue of the ossicles of the middle ear
noise (ringing, buzzing) in the ears without an external source
inﬂammation of the labyrinth of the inner ear
collection of skin cells and cholesterol in a sac within the middle ear
inﬂammation of the middle ear with bacterial infection and pus collection
benign tumor arising from the acoustic nerve in the brain
inﬂammation of the mastoid process (behind the ear)
inﬂammation of the eardrum

instructions.instructions: Give short deﬁnitions for the following medical terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. ENG [electronystagmography]

2. AS [left ear]

3. AD [right ear]

4. EENT [eyes, ears, nose, and throat/eyes, ears, nose and throat]

5. ENT [ears, nose, and throat/ears, nose and throat] 

6. PE tube [pressure-equalizing tube]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following abbreviations of terms relating to otology.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Dr. Jones specializes in pediatric ophthalmology. His examination of children with poor vision often leads to the diagnosis of [amblyopia/cataract/glaucoma], or lazy eye.

2. Stella’s near vision became progressively worse as she aged. Her physician told her that she had a common condition called [presbyopia/detached retina/anisocoria], which often develops beginning in middle age.

3. Matthew rubbed his itchy eyes constantly and thus spread his “pinkeye” or [conjunctivitis/blepharitis/myringitis] from one eye to the other. Dr. Chang prescribed antibiotics for this common condition, because Matthew had a purulent discharge suggestive of an infection.

4. As Paul’s [tinnitus/mastoiditis/otitis media] became progressively worse, his doctor worried that this ringing in his ears might be caused by a benign brain tumor, a/an [acoustic neuroma/cholesteatoma/glaucoma].

5. Before her second birthday, Sally had so many episodes of [suppurative otitis media/vertigo/otosclerosis] that Dr. Sills recommended the placement of PE tubes.

6. Sixty-eight-year-old Bob experienced blurred vision in the central portion of his visual ﬁeld. After careful examination of his [retina/cornea/sclera], his [ophthalmologist/optician/optometrist] diagnosed his condition as [macular degeneration/glaucoma/iritis]. The doctor explained that the form of this condition was atrophic or [dry/wet], causing photoreceptor rods and cones to die.

7. If Bob’s condition had been diagnosed as the [wet/dry] form, it might have been treated with 
 [laser photocoagulation/cryotherapy/intraocular lenses] to seal leaky blood vessels.

8. Sarah suddenly experienced bright ﬂashes of light in her right eye. She also told her physician that she had a sensation of a curtain being pulled over part of the visual ﬁeld in that eye. Her doctor examined her eye with [ophthalmoscopy/keratoplasty/tonometry] and determined that she had [retinal detachment/retinal refraction/diabetic retinopathy]. Corrective surgery, known as [scleral buckling/enucleation/vitrectomy], was recommended.  

9. Carol awakened with a sensation of dizziness or [vertigo/tinnitus/presbycusis] as she tried to get out of bed. She was totally incapacitated for several days and noticed hearing loss in her left ear. Her physician explained that ﬂuid called [endolymph/pus/mucus] had accumulated in her [cochlea/auditory tube/middle ear]  and her condition was [Meniere disease/otosclerosis/cholesteatoma]. He prescribed drugs to control her dizziness and nausea.

10. Patients with conductive hearing loss are helped by reconstruction of the [tympanic membrane/labyrinth/auditory tube], a procedure known as [myringoplasty/audiometry/otoscopy]. Patients with sensorineural hearing loss may be helped by a [cochlear implant/hearing aid/stapedectomy].

instructions.instructions: Select the correct term(s) to complete each sentence.
